author: Rob Cohen
title: Cardano Support for Point of Sale
description: Cardano has no easy Point-of-Sale software integration, and therefore requires expensive custom solutions for website payments.

assessments.note: BTCPay does describe itself as a self-hosted, open-source cryptocurrency payment processor. Furthermore, it states that it is secure, private, censorship-resistant and free. I like that. I've personally been searching for an open-source no-free, self-hosted, no-intermediary cryptocurrency payment processor and having one that integrates ADA would be excellent for the ecosystem, in my view. I know that it is not an easy thing to find - and having ADA included would be a boon. I think that the proposer has identified a clear case of an integration that merits attention and that will benefit the Cardano ecosystem. The proposed project to add Cardano support to BTCPay Server is something that would collectively advance the use of ADA & help to promote adoption. Effectively, I think the proposed project hits the nail on the head in terms of - increasing both utility & adoption of Cardano. I think that - if executed succesfully - the proposal would add value and more options to the Cardano ecosystem and its users and stakeholders.
I give a 1 for impact because, while it is an interesting idea, the proposal does not indicate a timeline so I cannot know whether the proposal will bring value to Cardano users in 2021.

Since the challenge is focused in the end-user in 2021 (or the next few years) I think this project has low impact. The data nowadays is that a very low percentage of BTC, e.g., is actually used to buy goods, since the currency is in its young stages – it is still growing in value and gaining maturity to actually become a tradable. Therefore, I think that in these few years to come by this won't be of much value.
Other than that, I would be useful to find some key metrics to analyze.
How big is the BTCpay market? Is 85,000 too much to enable this functionality? It is a large portion of the fund.

The proposer does not at all mention the ADApay solution that has already gone live and works with multiple Cardano wallets (Daedalus/Yoroi) out of the box. There is also no technical documentation describing the integration of the BTCpay protocol into Cardano.
It's a good idea to promote Cardano to wider usage via BTCPay Server which allows e-commerce websites payment.

The proposer clearly has inside technical and managerial experience from IOHK where he worked as Product Manager.This would imply full familiarity with the Cardano ethos, Haskell foundations, philosophy and general IOHK operations and vision. I think this is a clear advantage for the proposer. 
The IOHK website still hosts a webpage with information, confirming that he worked there:
https://iohk.io/en/team/rob-cohen
It states that "Rob joined IOHK after completing one of the company's Haskell courses in 2018.... He previously served in the military ... bachelor's degree in computer science and mathematics from Columbia  ... .bachelor's in economics and political science from Brown University.... Studying part-time at Georgia Tech to earn his master's degree in computer science...
So the relevant skill and experience seem to be in place. 
Although the proposal does not break down the budget into components (a potential weakness as the Community Advisor Assessment Guide asks that the budget be outlined clearly and broken down into identifiable items). Fortunately, the proposer did respond to a comment about the budget and stated that he would be required to pay 25-30% of this amount in taxes plus some funds would be used for overhead for a web presence and ensuring that legal precautions are taken. So, we have some budget breakdown provided - although not a full one. Also the unspecified funds for overhead and legal precautions - should be quantified. 
As regards future maintenance costs, the proposer does consider that (also in the comments) - and he maintains that if the API changes and ongoing development will be needed to support multi-assets - "a startup could be formed that would make this service hosted"... 
I didn't see a proposed timetable to complete the work. The proposal  would have been stronger if it included information on the timetable with clear milestones linked to time.

I give a 1 for feasibility because there is almost no detail for the work that needs to be completed. The proposer does not outline what kind of code needs to be written to integrate Cardano into BTCPay point of sale servers. He does not tell us what $85,000 is needed to do.
The budget is not well detailed and there and there is no timetable which allow us to verify if it's feasible in that time or not.

There is no technical documentation, metrics or timeline included in the proposal, the author does have prior experience as an IOHK PM but for the budget requested their needs to be more content unpacking the 'how' behind this integration.
The proposer is a former IOHK developers, so that's a plus. On the other hand, the combination of working as a sole developer for the initial phase and the amount requested might not be ideal.

Auditability.... The A word of Catalyst. The CA guidelines specify that an auditable proposal should have a roadmap with milestones and a ... time horizon for achievement.
This proposal does have a roadmap broken down by  Prototype Phase, MVP Phase and Version 2.0. However, no time horizon is provided. The proposed stages imply that a certain flow is implied. But no absolute or relative deadlines have been set and that does hamper auditability. 
We do have a clear description of the targeted problem as well as a clear solution. The lack of a timetable means that I subtract one star, yet the inclusion of a timetable would have improved auditability.
I give a 1 for auditability because no metrics or timeline really given. We have no way of measuring success, based on what is written in this proposal.
I'm missing KPI and metrics and a roadmap with milestones.
This proposal is lacking technical documentation, a timeline or any form of metrics/KPIs

Initial discussion to get the prototype running for the first 4-6 months are stated in the proposal, however, plan for MVP phase and other subsequent phases is not clearly laid out yet, including how the proposer plan to take it to the next level similar to the opennode.

solution: Adding Cardano support to BTCPay Server would enable easy web payments for ecommerce websites and online services.
experience:
\- Former IOHK Product & Project Manager for Hydra, Cardano Node, Multi-assets & Cardano Documentation
